Course.Title: SENIOR CAPSTONE
Course.Description: A software implementation course that integrates theory and practice in design and development of a large computer information system. Students select a project, and then search, design, code, test, document, demonstrate and present results to the class.

Sections.CourseDescription: A software implementation course that integrates theory and practice in design and development of a large computer information system. Students select a project, and then search, design, code, test, document, demonstrate and present results to the class.

Course.Title: SPECIAL TOPICS IN CS
Course.Description: Research study of areas in Computer Science influenced by contemporary developments as well as the interests and needs of students majoring in information technology. A maximum of nine semester hours may be taken in this area towards major electives.

Sections.CourseDescription: Research study of areas in Computer Science influenced by contemporary developments as well as the interests and needs of students majoring in information technology. A maximum of nine semester hours may be taken in this area towards major electives.

Sections.Comments: WENZHOU-KEAN STUDENTS ONLY APPROVED PETITION REQUIRED
Sections.Title: SPECIAL TOPICS IN CS

Course.Title: DATABASE SYSTEMS
Course.Description: Enterprise database management systems; database design; database implementation; storage and indexing; transaction processing concepts; data warehousing, data mining and online analytical processing (OLAP); emerging database applications.

Sections.CourseDescription: Enterprise database management systems; database design; database implementation; storage and indexing; transaction processing concepts; data warehousing, data mining and online analytical processing (OLAP); emerging database applications.
MeetingsDisplay: Tuesday, Thursday 1:00 PM - 2:15 PM WKU General Education Hall C404 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: DATABASE SYSTEMS

Course.Title: ADV ARTFCL INTELL
Course.Description: This course introduces the five fundamental topics of AI, 1) problem-solving, 2) reasoning and planning, 3) dealing with uncertainty, 4) learning, and 5) communication with perceiving and acting. The focus will be on the first three with an example of autonomous systems for the 5th one.

Sections.CourseDescription: This course introduces the five fundamental topics of AI, 1) problem-solving, 2) reasoning and planning, 3) dealing with uncertainty, 4) learning, and 5) communication with perceiving and acting. The focus will be on the first three with an example of autonomous systems for the 5th one.
MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Wednesday 4:00 PM - 5:15 PM WKU General Education Hall A207 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: ADV ARTFCL INTELL

Course.Title: SOFTWARE ASSURANCE
Course.Description: Concepts, practices and methodologies for ensuring integrity, security, and reliability in software code development, including processes and procedures that diminish the possibility of erroneous code, malicious code, or trap doors that could be introduced during development.

Sections.CourseDescription: Concepts, practices and methodologies for ensuring integrity, security, and reliability in software code development, including processes and procedures that diminish the possibility of erroneous code, malicious code, or trap doors that could be introduced during development.
MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Wednesday 8:30 AM - 9:45 AM WKU General Education Hall A205 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: SOFTWARE ASSURANCE

Course.Title: INTRO DESIGN & VISUAL CULTURE
Course.Description: An introduction to design as an essential human activity and as a primary creator of popular material culture. A wide range of trades and professions will be addressed. Required for BFA Graphic Design, BFA Interior Design, BID Industrial Design majors, elective for all others.

Sections.CourseDescription: An introduction to design as an essential human activity and as a primary creator of popular material culture. A wide range of trades and professions will be addressed. Required for BFA Graphic Design, BFA Interior Design, BID Industrial Design majors, elective for all others.

Course.Title: CRITICAL PERSP IN DESIGN
Course.Description: Seminar on contemporary topics in design. Emphasis upon theory and critical analysis as they apply to design. Design viewed in the broad context of cultural, technological and intellectual conditions that define modern and post-modern thought. Students will evaluate their personal design point of view and gain a critical understanding of the greater design landscape today. Topics to be covered will include Non-Western Design, sustainability, socially responsible design, temporary vs. permanent design and intention reinvention. An emphasis will be placed upon the need for interdisciplinary thinking and creative problem solving.

Sections.CourseDescription: Seminar on contemporary topics in design. Emphasis upon theory and critical analysis as they apply to design. Course.Title: SPECIAL TOPICS IN DESIGN
Course.Description: Studio/lecture in a specially chosen creative area of design, application- industrial design, interior design, visual communications or collaborative projects among these disciplines. Studio and writing assignments address special topics not covered in required or existing course offerings. Emphasis on expanding the student's vision of applied design.

Course.Title: ST:INTERACTIVE AD CON & DSN
Course.Description: Immersive online course structured like a new business pitch, with each student placed in the role of agency art director on the project.  Course will begin with a creative kickoff and conclude with the client presentation.  Students will be responsible for generating concepts, designing comps, and presenting their ideas.  By closely emulating the agency pitch process, students will be better able to compete for, and succeed in, their first creative position.

Sections.CourseDescription: Immersive online course structured like a new business pitch, with each student placed in the role of agency art director on the project. MeetingsDisplay: Tuesday 9:30 AM - 3:20 PM WKU Gehekai Hall F411A (Lecture)
Sections.Title: St: Experiential/Events

Course.Title: PRINCIPLES OF ECONOMCS I
Course.Description: The American Economy; aggregate economics with emphasis on the relationships of income, consumption, savings and investment; money and banking, economic growth and the role of government. The 1020-1021 sequence may be taken in either order.

Sections.CourseDescription: The American Economy; aggregate economics with emphasis on the relationships of income, consumption, savings and investment; money and banking, economic growth and the role of government. The 1020-1021 sequence may be taken in either order.

Sections.Comments: WENZHOU-KEAN STUDENTS ONLY. Business Students first.
Sections.Title: PRINCIPLES OF ECONOMCS I
